text: HIV-1 <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> potentiates TNF - induced NF-kappa B activation and cytotoxicity by altering the cellular redox state .

This study demonstrates that human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein amplifies the activity of tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) , a cytokine that stimulates HIV-1 replication through activation of NF-kappa B .

In HeLa cells stably transfected with the HIV-1 tat gene ( HeLa-tat cells ) , expression of the <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein enhanced both TNF - induced activation of NF-kappa B and TNF - mediated cytotoxicity .
A similar potentiation of TNF effects was observed in Jurkat T cells and HeLa cells treated with soluble <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein .
TNF - mediated activation of NF-kappa B and cytotoxicity involves the intracellular formation of reactive oxygen intermediates .
Therefore , <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated effects on the cellular redox state were analyzed .

In both T cells and HeLa cells HIV-1 <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> suppressed the expression of <extra_id_0> Mn-dependent superoxide dismutase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> Mn-SOD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , a mitochondrial enzyme that is part of the cellular defense system against oxidative stress .

text: Thus , <extra_id_0> Mn-SOD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> RNA protein levels and activity were markedly reduced in the presence of <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: Thus , our experiments demonstrate that the C-terminal region of HIV-1 <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is required to suppress <extra_id_0> Mn-SOD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression and to induce pro-oxidative conditions reflected by a drop in reduced glutathione ( GSH ) and the GSH : oxidized GSH ( GSSG ) ratio .
